results.title: Power from the snow
results.creator_credit: Gunnar Isakson, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme. Shows the commencement of work in 1949, surveying the area and design of the first part of the project. Culminates in the official opening by the Prime Minister of the new Munyang Power Station, a few miles downstream from Guthega Dam which supplies it with water. Work continues on this great project, estimated to take twenty-five years to complete. Over an area of 3,000 square miles, men and machines reshape the land to supply Australia with light, and power.

results.title: North to the sun
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of the development of the rich tropical area around Cairns in the northern parts of Queensland. Shows the primary industries of the region including timber, maize and tobacco; its potentialities for development and its attraction as a homeland for newcomers.

results.title: The Mount Hagen Show
results.creator_credit: Boris Cook and Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: A mass gathering of highland tribes of diverse customs was indicative of the beginnings of unity and prosperity in Papua and New Guinea. This was the hope expressed by Lord de L’Isle when he declared the Mount Hagen Show open. But it is only the beginning. The response of brightly painted feather bedecked natives to the throb of drums; the incongruousness of their participation in bicycle racing and dodgem cars; the mixed expressions of curiosity and distrust amongst the native spectators, clearly show that the path to change is a long one.

results.title: The Konrads: swim champions
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Indicates the swimming and training methods of John and Ilsa Konrads and other swimmers of the 1950s as well as some from the past such as “Boy” Charlton and Bonnie Mealing.

results.title: Keep it green
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: One-third of the world’s agricultural production is destroyed each year by pests and diseases. Geographical isolation has helped protect Australia so far, but with increasing frequency and speed of modern communication the risk of their accidental introduction becomes greater every year. Plant Quarantine Inspectors check cargoes and passengers’ baggage, as they come into the country. Within industries such as sugar and rice, scientists work to improve commercial varieties and reduce disease.

results.title: It needn't happen
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Warns against accidents to small children in the home through the example of a little girl, the accidents that might have happened and how they could be prevented. Boiling water, medicine and sharp objects left within reach of the child, and over-boisterous games are all potentially dangerous.

results.title: The Invisible link
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, Geoffrey Collings, Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A brief explanation of radio broadcasting in Australia. Shows scenes in the Australian Broadcasting Commission’s studios and in the Postmaster-General’s transmission stations through which typical commercial and non-commercial programs are being broadcast. Use of wireless in ships, aeroplanes, police cars and ambulances, including a symphony concert, a radio play and the children’s “Kindergarten of the Air”.

results.title: The Talented Mr. Ripley [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Tom Sternberg, William Horberg, Miramax Films and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Patricia Highsmith, The Talented Mr. Ripley is a story about a charismatic sociopath who would rather be a ‘fake somebody than a real nobody’.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Minghella, Tom Sternberg, William Horberg, Miramax Films and Paramount Pictures
results.description: Based on the novel by Patricia Highsmith, “The Talented Mr. Ripley” is a story about a charismatic sociopath who would rather be a ‘fake somebody than a real nobody’. Living and working in New York as a washroom attendant, Tom Ripley is faced with an opportunity he cannot refuse when a wealthy shipping tycoon mistakes him for a Princeton classmate of his son, Dickie. He proposes that Tom go to Italy in an attempt to bring his playboy son back home. When Tom finds and befriends both Dickie and is girlfriend, neither are aware the extremes Tom will go to in order to claim their lives as his own. Cast includes: Matt Damon, Gwyneth Paltrow, Jude Law, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Cate Blanchett.
